column1: Denton is a city in and the county seat of Denton County
column2: Texas
column3: United States. With an estimated population of 141
column5: it is the 24th-most populous city in Texas
column6: the 196th-most populous city in the United States
column7: and the 12th-most populous city in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex.

column1: A Texas land grant led to the formation of Denton County in 1846 and the city was incorporated in 1866. Both were named after pioneer and Texas militia captain John B. Denton. The arrival of a railroad line in the city in 1881 spurred population
column2: and the establishment of the University of North Texas in 1890 and Texas Woman's University in 1901 distinguished the city from neighboring regions. After the construction of Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport finished in 1974
column3: the city had more rapid growth; as of 2011
column4: Denton was the seventh-fastest growing city with a population over 100
column5: 000 in the country.

column1: Located on the far north end of the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex in North Texas on Interstate 35
column2: Denton is known for its active music life; the North Texas State Fair and Rodeo
column3: Denton Arts and Jazz Festival
column4: and 35 Denton Music Festival attract over 300
column5: 000 people to the city each year. The city experiences hot
column6: humid summers and relatively few extreme weather events. Its diverse citizenry is represented by a nonpartisan city council
column7: and numerous county and state departments have offices in the city. With over 45
column8: 000 students enrolled at the two universities located within its city limits
column9: Denton is often characterized as a college town. As a result of the universities' growth
column10: educational services play a large role in the city's economy. Residents are served by the Denton County Transportation Authority
column11: which provides commuter rail and bus service to the area.

column1: The formation of Denton is closely tied with that of Denton County. White settlement of the area began in the middle of the 1800s when William S. Peters of Kentucky obtained a land grant from the Texas Congress and named it Peters Colony. After initial settlement in the southeast part of the county in 1843
column2: the Texas Legislature voted to form Denton County in 1846. Both the county and the town were named for John B. Denton
column3: a preacher and lawyer who was killed in 1841 during a skirmish with Kichai people in what is now Tarrant County. Pickneyville and Alton were selected as the county seat before Denton was named for that position in 1857. That year
column4: a commission laid out the city and named the first streets.

column3: approximately one-half of the downtown Square burned down in what was later called the "Texas Troubles." Fires occurred in ten Texas communities that day
column4: including Dallas and Pilot Point and were quickly attributed to a slave insurrection. By the end of July
column5: vigilante justice took hold and "[r]egularly constituted law-enforcement agencies stepped aside to allow the vigilantes to do their work. Although no hard evidence was ever adduced to prove the guilt of a single alleged black arsonist or white abolitionist
column6: many unfortunates of both classes were nevertheless hanged for their alleged crimes."In February 1861
column7: a statewide referendum was held and Texans voted to join the Confederate States of America.

column1: Denton incorporated in 1866; its first mayor was J.B. Sawyer.  As the city expanded beyond its original boundaries (which extended half of a mile in every direction from center of the public square)
column2: it became an agricultural trade center for the mill and cottage industries. The arrival of the Texas and Pacific Railway in 1881 gave Denton its first rail connection and brought an influx of people to the area.  North Texas Normal College
column3: now the University of North Texas
column4: was established in 1890
column5: and the Girls' Industrial College
column6: now Texas Woman's University
column7: was founded in 1901. As the universities increased in size
column8: their impact on Denton's economy and culture increased. Electricity came to Denton beginning in 1905 with the creation of Denton Municipal Electric.

column1: Like many cities in the Southern United States
column2: Denton has a legacy of racial segregation stemming from the trans-Atlantic slave trade. In 1918
column3: the Daughters of the Confederacy gifted the City of Denton with a monument entitled "Our Confederate Soldiers." At the base of the monument two water fountains are present
column4: one engraved "whites" and the other engraved "colored." The monument was placed on the grounds of the Denton County Courthouse.

column2: "Freedmen Settlements" were started throughout the South. One Freedman Settlement called Quakertown
column3: thrived just south of what is now Texas Woman's University until around 1920
column4: when the residents were forcibly removed by the City government to make way for a park. Quakertown's Black children were served separately from white children by the Frederick Douglass School. Originally scheduled to open in September 1913
column5: it was mysteriously burned down the Sunday night prior to the scheduled opening. It was rebuilt and in 1949 renamed the "Fred Moore School."

column1: Although the United States Supreme Court ordered school integration in the seminal Brown v. Board of Education decision of 1954
column2: Denton public schools remained segregated until 1963
column3: when the local school board voted unanimously to integrate them. Integration was not complete in Denton public schools until 1967
column4: 13 years after the Brown v. Board of Education decision. The federal deadline for complete integration of schools in Texas was September 1
column6: the local chapter of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows
column7: or I.O.O.F.
column8: deeded a cemetery to the City of Denton which contained a "whites only" deed restriction preventing the burial of Black people at the now-City-owned cemetery. The deed restriction was allegedly no longer enforced by the 1950s
column9: however the unlawful restriction was not removed by City action until 2016.

column1: Denton grew from a population of 26
column3: 063 in 1980. Its connection to the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex via I-35E and I-35W played a major role in the growth
column4: and the opening of Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport in 1974 led to an increase in population. In the 1980s
column5: heavy manufacturing companies like Victor Equipment Company and Peterbilt joined older manufacturing firms such as Moore Business Forms and Morrison Milling Company in Denton. The population jumped from 66
column8: Houston-based real estate company United Equities purchased the 100-block of Fry Street and announced that several of the historic buildings would be demolished and the businesses displaced to accommodate a new mixed-use commercial center. The proposal drew opposition from some residents
column9: who sought to preserve the area as a historic and cultural icon for the city. The Denton City Council approved a new proposal for the area from Dinerstein Cos in 2010.

column1: Denton is located on the northern edge of the Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area. These three cities form the area known as the "Golden Triangle of North Texas." According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 89.316 square miles (231.33 km2)
column3: of which 87.952 square miles (227.79 km2) is land and 1.364 square miles (3.53 km2) is covered by water. The city lies in the northeast edge of the Bend Arch–Fort Worth Basin
column4: which is characterized by flat terrain. Elevation ranges from 500 to 900 feet (150 to 270 m). Part of the city is located atop the Barnett Shale
column5: a geological formation believed to contain large quantities of natural gas. Lewisville Lake
column6: a man-made reservoir
column7: is located 15 miles (24 km) south of the city.

column2: humid summers and cool winters
column3: Denton's climate is characterized as humid subtropical and is within USDA hardiness zone 8a. The city's all-time high temperature is 113 °F (45 °C)
column4: recorded in 1954. Dry winds affect the area in the summer and can bring temperatures of over 100 °F (38 °C)
column5: although the average summer temperature highs range from 91 to 96 °F (33 to 36 °C) between June and August. The all-time recorded low is −3 °F (−19 °C)
column6: and the coolest month is January
column7: with daily low temperatures averaging 33 °F (1 °C). Denton lies on the southern end of what is commonly referred to as "Tornado Alley"; the National Weather Service occasionally issues tornado watches
column8: although tornadoes rarely form in the city. The city receives about 37.7 inches (96 cm) of rain per year. Flash floods and severe thunderstorms are frequent occurrences during spring. Average snowfall in Denton is similar to the Dallas–Fort Worth average of 2.4 inches (6.1 cm) per year.

column1: Denton is home to several annual artistic and cultural events that cater to residents and tourists. The annual North Texas State Fair and Rodeo began in 1928 and promotes the cowboy culture of Texas. In addition to a rodeo
column2: the event features several local country rock performances
column3: pageants
column4: and food contests. Hosted by the North Texas State Fairgrounds since 1948
column5: the fair brings in over 150
column6: 000 people during its nine-day run.

column1: The Denton Municipal Airport has hosted the annual Denton Airshow since 1998. The event includes aerial demonstrations and airplane exhibits; it attracted over 10
column2: 000 attendees in 2012. Other events in the city include an annual Redbud Festival
column3: the Fiesta on the Square
column4: and the Thin Line Documentary Film Fest. Denton houses the largest community garden in the United States
column5: specifically Shiloh Field Community Garden
column6: which measures at 14.5 acres of land.

column1: The local independent music scene in Denton has emerged alongside of Denton's academic music establishments
column2: including the University of North Texas College of Music. The city's live music venues are largely supported by Denton's college-town atmosphere
column3: although show attendance is bolstered by area residents. The Dallas Observer features a column on Denton's local music scene. In 2007 and 2008
column4: Denton's music scene received feature attention from The Guardian
column5: Pop Matters
column6: and The New York Times. Paste Magazine named Denton's music scene the best in the United States in 2008. The city-sponsored Denton Arts and Jazz Festival attracts over 200
column7: 000 people each year for live music
column10: and recreation at Civic Center Park. Bands such as Tower of Power
column12: and Arturo Sandoval have performed at the festival
column13: as well as jazz groups from the University of North Texas. With hopes of creating a live music event similar to South by Southwest
column14: Denton held the first annual North by 35 Music Festival
column17: the Huffington Post listed Denton as the number-one emerging cultural hot spot in Texas to visit
column18: while referring to Denton as "Practically an indie band factory at this point..."

column2: bordered by Oak
column3: Hickory
column4: Locust
column5: and Elm Streets
column6: is a cultural and political hub of the city. At its center is the Denton County Courthouse-on-the-Square
column7: which includes local government offices and a museum showcasing area history and culture.Listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places
column8: the former county courthouse was restored for the Texas Sesquicentennial in 1986. The positive response to the renovation sparked a downtown revitalization program that generated new jobs and reinvestment capital. The downtown square is populated by local shops and restaurants
column9: some of which have been in business since the 1940s. Each year
column10: the downtown square is adorned with lights and spotlighted during the Denton Holiday Lighting Festival.The Denton Confederate Soldier Monument
column12: arched monument topped with a statue of a Confederate soldier
column13: was erected in 1918 in the Denton Square on the courthouse lawn by the Daughters of the Confederacy. The monument was controversial
column14: and though previous attempts to remove it were unsuccessful
column15: the Denton County Commissioners unanimously approved its removal on June 9.

column1: Denton is the county seat of Denton County. From 1914 to 1959
column2: the City of Denton used a mayor–city commission system
column3: but a charter adopted in 1959 created a council–manager form of city government. Residents elect a mayor
column4: four single-member district council members
column5: and two at-large members. The city manager is appointed by the Denton City Council. Council terms are for two years
column6: with a maximum of three consecutive terms
column7: and elections are held each year in May. Utilities are administered by Denton Municipal Utilities; the city provides water
column10: drainage and solid waste service. The electric utility
column12: has been in operation since 1905. In 2009
column13: DME began providing 40 percent of its energy to customers through renewable resources. The City of Denton Water Utilities Department serves the city's water demand. Atmos Energy provides the city's natural gas. Denton is a part of the Sister Cities International program and maintains cultural and economic exchange programs with its sister cities
column14: Madaba in Jordan and San Nicolás de los Garza in Mexico.The city of Denton is a voluntary member of the North Central Texas Council of Governments association
column15: the purpose of which is to coordinate individual and collective local governments and facilitate regional solutions

column1: Denton is located within U.S. House 26th Congressional district
column2: which is represented by Michael C. Burgess. In the US Congress
column3: the city is in the 30th District in the Texas Senate
column4: represented by Republican Craig Estes. It is in the 64th District of the Texas House of Representatives
column5: represented by Republican Myra Crownover since 2001.Several Texas state agencies have facilities in the city
column6: including a Texas Workforce Center
column7: a Texas Department of Public Safety office
column8: a Texas Department of Criminal Justice office
column9: and a Denton District Parole Office. The Denton State Supported Living Center
column11: is the largest residential facility for people with developmental disabilities in Texas. The center serves an 18-county area and employs approximately 1
column12: 500 people. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has its Region VI headquarters in Denton.

column1: Along with much of the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex
column2: Denton has grown rapidly in recent years
column3: becoming the seventh fastest-growing city in the U.S. with a population over 100
column4: 000 between 2010 and 2011. The city has a population of 113
column5: 383 according to the 2010 United States Census
column6: making it the 230th largest city in the United States and the 27th largest in Texas. The population density was 1
column7: 289.1 people per square mile. There were 46
column9: 060 households in the city. The racial makeup of the city was 73.8% White
column14: and 3.2% from two or more races. Hispanics or Latinos of any race comprised 21.2% of the population. The median income for a household was $44
column15: 415 in 2010. The per capita income was $22
column16: 940. About 20.3% of the population were below the poverty line.

column1: Denton Independent School District (DISD) provides the public primary and secondary educational system in the city. The district comprises four comprehensive high schools (Braswell
column2: Denton
column3: Guyer
column4: and Ryan)
column5: one alternative high school
column6: and multiple elementary and middle schools. Small portions of the city extend into the Argyle and Sanger school districts. Denton is also host to several private schools with religious affiliations and alternative education models. According to the 2010 United States Census
column7: 35.1% of all adults over the age of 25 in Denton have obtained a bachelor's degree
column8: as compared to the state average of 25.8%
column9: and 86.1% of residents over the age of 25 have earned a high school diploma
column10: as compared to the state average of 80%.The high school residential program Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science

column1: The Roman Catholic Immaculate Conception Catholic School
column2: a K-8 school of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Worth
column3: opened in 1995. Construction on the current facility started on July 15
column5: with its opening on August 19
column6: 2002.The charter school operator Life's Beautiful Educational Centers Inc. (closed 1999) operated the school L.O.V.E. in Denton.

column1: Denton is served by the Denton Public Library
column2: which has three branches: Emily Fowler Central Library
column3: North Branch Library
column4: and South Branch Library.

column1: The University of North Texas (UNT) in Denton is the flagship university of the University of North Texas System
column2: which also includes the UNT Health Science Center in Fort Worth
column3: the University of North Texas at Dallas
column4: and UNT Dallas College of Law. With an enrollment of nearly 38
column6: it's the sixth largest university in Texas. The university is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools (SACS). Its College of Music
column7: the first school to offer a degree in the field of jazz studies

column1: Texas Woman's University (TWU) is a public university in Denton with two health science center branches in Dallas and Houston. Founded in 1901
column2: the university enrolls more than 13
column3: 000 undergraduates and graduates. Men have been admitted to TWU since 1972 but make up less than ten percent of the university. TWU's College of Nursing is the second largest in Texas and in the top 20 of largest nursing programs in the United States
column4: and the school's nursing doctoral program is the largest in the world.

column1: North Central Texas College (NCTC) is a public community college based in Gainesville
column2: Texas. Starting in the 2019-2020 school year
column3: North Central Texas College partnered with First State Bank to open a branch campus in downtown Denton. Located in the former Denton Record-Chronicle building
column4: the campus focuses on accounting
column5: business
column6: biology
column7: early childhood education

the Denton Record-Chronicle has been the newspaper of record for Denton. When it was acquired by Belo Corporation in 1999
column3: the newspaper had a circulation of 16
column4: 000. The North Texas Daily and The Lasso provide daily and weekly news to students at the University of North Texas and Texas Woman's University. The city's public television station

column1: Two major hospitals operate in Denton: Medical City Denton and Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Denton are both full-service hospitals with differing capacities: 208 beds and 255 beds
column2: respectively. Each employs more than 800 employees and are licensed with emergency services.

column1: In response to a 2014 city referendum prohibiting hydraulic fracturing (fracking) that passed with 59% of the vote
column2: Texas enacted a law specifying "the exclusive jurisdiction of this state to regulate oil and gas operations in this state and the express preemption of local regulation of those operations"
column3: though it allows some "commercially reasonable" rules. Denton says it will "continue to enforce our current regulations to protect the health and safety of our residents
column4: but we do not know how the operators or courts will react".

column1: The Green Tree Estates is a low-income mobile home neighborhood with an estimated 50 residents currently living on the property. The city of Denton annexed the neighborhood in 2011
column2: but the land remained as private property. Residents claim that landowner
column3: Don Roddy
column4: was supposed to install infrastructure to connect to the city of Denton's water supply but never did. The residents living on the Green Tree Estates property relied on the privately-owned well for water.After numerous fines for failing to bring the system into compliance
column5: Roddy announced that he would shut down the well-based water system completely on November 15th
column6: 2019. The water from that systems was murky yellow
column7: orange
column10: Denton Mayor Chris Watts issued a declaration of local state of disaster for the Green Tree Estates neighborhood and two days later
column11: the City of Denton began sending tanks of water to Green Tree Estates.

column1: The owner and well operator of Green Tree Estates
column2: Don Roddy
column3: turned off the private well on November 15th
column4: 2019.  It was later reported that Roddy had reached out to the Texas Commission of Environmental Quality and reported some of the connections were illegal
column5: allowing Roddy to disconnect service at any time.  On October 29 a neighborhood meeting took place to inform the Green Tree Estates residents of the situation and to collect feedback. However
column6: the majority of the residents are Hispanic and few speak English so many residents did not acquire understanding from the meeting. In the meeting
column7: Denton director of utilities
column9: estimated that the cost of bringing in a modern water system to the neighborhood would exceed $500
column10: 000. A representative from the Public Utility Commission reported that the city is not in a position to force Roddy to keep the water system on any longer. On November 11 at an additional meeting
column13: discussed how declaring the situation as an emergency would allow for temporary funding to ease the situation until a more permanent plan could be put into action. A translator is also present at this meeting to convey information to the Green Tree Estates residents.  On November 13
column14: 2019 Denton Mayor Chris Watts issued a declaration of local state of disaster for the Green Tree Estates neighborhood.  This allowed for 90-day temporary funding for the Green Tree Estates residents.On November 15
column16: a special city council meeting was held to discuss how emergency funds will be spent. The city decided to purchase 14 275-gallon tanks to fill with water and distribute them to families of the Green Tree Estates. The city also plans to refill the tanks three days a week. Green Tree Estates residents expressed their concerns that this was not going to be enough water.On December 10
column17: 2019 the Denton City Council agreed to extend an emergency declaration over water service to the Green Tree Estates until February. In the meantime
column18: plans to conduct courtesy home inspections and collect a census on property owners and tenants are made and considered key to settling on a long-term solution.

column1: City leaders asked for the cooperation from the Green Tree Estates residents regarding conducting home inspections as well as helping to identify which residents owned their properties and which were tenants. Through these actions
column2: advocacy groups and the city of Denton could work together on the needed easements for new water lines. City manager
column3: Todd Hileman
column4: said that the city's ability to get those easements was "key" to settling on a long-term solution. However
column5: residents of the Green Tree Estates expressed confusion stating that they didn't understand what was being asked of them.  An attorney representing the Green Tree Estates neighborhood advised the residents to hire their own inspectors
column6: resulting in none of the 14 homes accepting courtesy inspections from the city of Denton. The residents are seeking to calculate the total costs before deciding to connect to Denton's water system which means they need more time for the assessments and work. The residents of Green Tree Estates are asking the city of Denton for an extension on the public emergency until May 2021.As of February 4
column8: none of the 14 families living in the Green Tree Estates had completed the courtesy inspections of their homes from the city of Denton. Instead
column9: the neighborhood's attorney recommended the residents bring in their own inspectors. A Univision television reporter reported that "the residents want to calculate the total costs before deciding to connect to the system." Lastly
column10: the residents told the deputy director of public affairs that they needed more time for the assessments and the work and asked the city council to extend the public emergency until May 2021. Some council members were uneasy with the request for the extension to continue for more than a year
column11: but other members were more comfortable with it as long as progress is shown to be made. At a February 18
column12: 2020 the Denton city council said that it plans to revisit the issue April 21
column13: to give residents and city officials time to see which owners would be able to connect if the water main.   The expressed concern that residents may not actually connect to the water main if it is supplied.  However
column14: this idea is currently on hold due to  concerns that many residents living at Green Tree estates will not be able to afford the fees required by the contractors
column15: questions regarding which homes are up to code and concerns on the quality
column17: and structural integrity of the private water system.

column2: which split in Hillsboro south of the Metroplex and come north through Dallas and Fort Worth respectively
column3: rejoin near the University of North Texas campus in the southwest part of Denton to form Interstate 35 as it continues north on its way to Oklahoma. Loop 288 partially encircles the city; it passes through the northern limits of the city by C. H. Collins Athletic Complex and the eastern side near Golden Triangle Mall. Highway 77 and 377 go through the historic town square and Highway 380 connects Denton to Frisco and McKinney in the east and Decatur in the west. Denton Enterprise Airport is a public airport located 3 miles (4.8 km) west of the central business district (CBD) of Denton. This airport serves as home to various cargo and charter operators as well as two flight schools. A new terminal opened in 2008
column4: but as of June 2008 no scheduled commuter service is in place.

column1: Denton is served by the Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA)
column2: which operates local bus service and regional rail to Lewisville and Carrollton
column3: with connections to Dallas' DART rail system. In 2011
column4: Downtown Denton Transit Center and Medpark Station opened as commuter rail stations on DCTA's A-train
column5: which now has five stations and connects to the Green Line of Dallas Area Rapid Transit's (DART) Green Line at Trinity Mills Station. The two transit companies
column6: along with the Trinity Rail Express (TRE) of Fort Worth
column7: offer regional passes to be used on any of the three systems. As of August
column9: rides between the first two (DDTC and Medpark) and the last two (Hebron and Trinity Mills) are "fare-free
column10:
though any ride to or through the 3rd stop (Lewisville Lake) will require a paid pass. DCTA states this will relocate downtown parking needs to the underutilized space at Medpark station, and enhance mobility in Downtown Denton, including for students, as well as for residents of Hebron who connect to the DART system one stop away at Trinity Mills. DCTA also operates the Connect local bus service within the cities of Denton and Lewisville and special university shuttles. All Connect services (not the A-train) are free of charge for students at the University of North Texas who swipe their ID at the bus entrance. Special Programs for Aging Needs (SPAN), a non-profit organization, offers paratransit service for senior citizens and people with disabilities of all ages.


== Notable people ==
Mario Bennett - Denton High graduate and NBA player from 1995 to 2000 (born in Denton).
Bob Castleberry - won $10 million in the Publishers Clearinghouse Sweepstakes, quit his sales job, ran for Denton's mayor and won in 1990 (born in Denton).
Jim Chamblee - MLB 3rd Baseman (born in Denton).
Shirley Cothran– 1975 Miss America (born in Denton County, Texas and Denton High graduate).
Herschel Evans – jazz musician (born in Denton).
Phyllis George – 1971 Miss America, First Lady of Kentucky (1979–83); businesswoman, actress, and sportscaster.
Abner Haynes – American Football League Rookie of the Year and MVP 1960 (born in Denton).
Austin Jackson - MLB player (born in Denton).
Ralph Kirshbaum - classical cellist (born in Denton, raised in Tyler, Texas).
Corey Knebel - MLB pitcher (born in Denton).
Jason Lee – actor, skateboarder.
Ray Peterson - 1950s/1960s pop singer (born in Denton).
Ann Sheridan – actress (born in Denton).
Sly Stone –  Sly & The Family Stone founder (born in Denton).
Charles 'Tex' Watson – Manson Family murderer (born Farmersville, Texas; later moved to Denton).
Mike Wiebe – musician (The Riverboat Gamblers), actor and stand-up comedian
